an3.66:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Nandaka was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
an3.66:4.3: Then Sāḷha, Migāra’s grandson, and Rohaṇa, Pekhuṇiya’s grandson went up to Venerable Nandaka,
an3.66:4.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an3.66:4.5: Then Venerable Nandaka said to Sāḷha:
an3.66:5.1: “Please, Sāḷha, don’t rely on oral transmission, lineage, testament, canonical authority, logic, inference, reasoned contemplation, acceptance of a view after consideration, the appearance of competence, or respect for your teacher.
an3.66:5.2: But when you know for yourselves: ‘These things are unwholesome, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering’, then you should give them up.
an3.66:6.1: What do you think, Sāḷha? Is greed real?”
an3.66:8.1: “‘Covetousness’ is what I mean by this.
an3.66:8.2: A person who is greedy and covetous kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
an3.66:10.1: “What do you think, Sāḷha? Is hate real?”
an3.66:12.1: “‘Ill will’ is what I mean by this.
an3.66:12.2: A hateful and malicious person kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
an3.66:14.1: “What do you think, Sāḷha? Is delusion real?”
an3.66:16.1: “‘Ignorance’ is what I mean by this.
an3.66:16.2: A person who is deluded and ignorant kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
an3.66:18.1: “What do you think, Sāḷha, are these things wholesome or unwholesome?”
an3.66:24.1: “When you undertake them, do they lead to harm and suffering, or not?”
an3.66:24.2: Or how do you see this?”
an3.66:25.1: “When you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering.
an3.66:26.2: ‘Please, don’t rely on oral transmission, lineage, testament, canonical authority, logic, inference, reasoned contemplation, acceptance of a view after consideration, the appearance of competence, or respect for your teacher.
an3.66:26.3: But when you know for yourselves:
an3.66:26.4: “These things are unwholesome, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering”, then you should give them up’—that’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an3.66:27.1: Please, Sāḷha, don’t rely on oral transmission, lineage, testament, canonical authority, logic, inference, reasoned contemplation, acceptance of a view after consideration, the appearance of competence, or respect for your teacher.
an3.66:27.2: But when you know for yourselves:
an3.66:27.3: ‘These things are wholesome, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness’, then you should acquire them and keep them.
an3.66:28.1: What do you think? Is contentment real?”
an3.66:30.1: “‘Satisfaction’ is what I mean by this.
an3.66:30.2: A person who is content and satisfied doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
an3.66:32.1: What do you think? Is love real?”
an3.66:34.1: “‘Good will’ is what I mean by this.
an3.66:34.2: A loving and kind-hearted person doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
an3.66:36.1: “What do you think, Sāḷha? Is understanding real?”
an3.66:38.1: “‘Knowledge’ is what I mean by this.
an3.66:38.2: A person who understands and knows doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
an3.66:40.1: “What do you think, Sāḷha, are these things wholesome or unwholesome?”
an3.66:46.1: “When you undertake them, do they lead to welfare and happiness, or not?
an3.66:46.2: Or how do you see this?”
an3.66:47.1: “When you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness.
an3.66:48.2: ‘Please, don’t rely on oral transmission, lineage, testament, canonical authority, logic, inference, reasoned contemplation, acceptance of a view after consideration, the appearance of competence, or respect for your teacher.
an3.66:48.3: But when you know for yourselves:
an3.66:48.4: “These things are wholesome, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness”, then you should acquire them and keep them’—that’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an3.66:49.1: Then that noble disciple is rid of desire, rid of ill will, unconfused, aware, and mindful. They meditate spreading a heart full of love …
an3.66:49.4: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way they spread a heart full of equanimity above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
an3.66:49.6: ‘There is this, there is what is worse than this, there is what is better than this, and there is an escape beyond the scope of perception.’
an3.66:49.7: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
an3.66:49.8: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
an3.66:49.9: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
an3.66:50.2: ‘Formerly there was greed, which was unwholesome. Now there is none, so that’s wholesome.
an3.66:50.3: Formerly there was hate, which was unwholesome. Now there is none, so that’s wholesome.
an3.66:50.4: Formerly there was delusion, which was unwholesome. Now there is none, so that’s wholesome.’
an3.66:50.5: So in the present life they live without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”
